title: Will the US or the UN impose any new sanctions on Iran before 18 October 2016?
preds: adding my voice to the consensus that this one should resolve
Does this count as actual sanctions?
news re. sanctions per Iranian hacking and
If a reason is needed the US charges over cyber attacks will fit the bill

I believe that they will not place sanctions on Iran because sanctions have already been placed. In addition, it takes quite a while in order for the US government to agree on anything, and in the midst of the election, America will be otherwise preoccupied.

The US will likely not agree to any new sanctions on Iran before said date because the republicans in congress are extremely against the Nuclear Plan, and President Obama will likely not risk a move that good upset democratic support right before an election. Also, Iran has mostly followed the restorations set by the sanction, so it's unlikely that new sanctions will be added unless something changes.

The nuclear deal suggests that new sanctions are unlikely. Iran has mostly followed the terms of the nuclear deal; President Obama wouldn’t want to go back on the agreement and betray US allies. The GOP cannot successfully pass sanctions unilaterally at this point. However, it is possible that Iran does something that justifies further sanctions.

My prediction: 20%
The US and UN have already imposed many sanctions, and with the US dealing with it’s own issues (Trump), I doubt much will be done to Iran. Also Iran has been laying low currently and doesn’t want to provoke the wrath of either the US or UN anytime soon.

I believe Connor has some good points about the inability of the United States Government to pass bills and sanctions. I also do not foresee Iran in the near future doing any nuclear tests or anything to provoke more attention about their nuclear program, however, Iran did a test in October of 2015 and sanctions were issued by January of 2016, so due to this quickness they have passed the sanctions in the past I give a higher probability of this occurring than Connor.

The US dropped some harsh sanctions for the ballistic missile test. Though Iran publicly denounced the sanctions, the economic and political implications of testing their luck again with more tests and nuclear productions would not be a smart move. With that said, it seems unlikely that the US will have to step into diplomacy sometime in the near future in order to control Iran's nuclear production process.

Moving up by 1% my well above consensus 90 to 91%. 
Rationale: 
UN sanctions remain a 0 probability considering the Russians & Chinese veto.  Yet, signals of a US sanction continue.
Up 10%. Token US response even though not a good idea.

With momentum gaining after the Spring recess, the Senate and House will most likely move forward with sanctions against Iran - given the last two missile launches.  With Republican control of the Congress, it is unlikely that such a bill would be formulated or co-sponsored if there was an unlikely possibility of the bill being passed.   Doing so before the November elections, is is highly probable that such an outcome can occur.   On the UN front, with Russia and China holding veto power in the Security Council, passing a resolution on new sanctions against Iran is most unlikely.
http://www.wsj.com/articles/the-u-s-senate-takes-on-iran-1458605304 there seems to be a fairly bipartisan consensus to get something passed

Sanctions are not so long ago removed and restore them in the near future will show no consistency in decisions. Launching missiles can accelerate this process, whether Iran is ready to accept new sanctions - under question. Conflicts with neighbors also will accelerate the adoption of new sanctions, I start with a lower probability. The Iranian leadership is now more loyal than in the past.
That darn fine print in the U.N. resolution against Iran missile tests! It appears that those recent  these tests are legal!
Iran to U.S.: it's just a coincidence that the Bowman Avenue Dam hackers ran their attack from a location next door to our military intelligence headquarters. Honest to Betsy!
Obama and Iran have a lot riding on the Iran nuclear deal. They are both very motivated not to cause sanctions to occur.
US is pushing for sanctions in the UN Security council. whether or not Russia blocks them, the US may have its own response. Seems more likely than not based on the probabilities.

"Resolution 2231, which was brought into effect in January, used the term “calls upon” Iran to avoid activity for ballistic missiles. While the U.S. and Israel claim that Iran is banned from testing ballistic missiles, Russia and Iran claim that the term “calls upon” is not legally binding." (@cdob63, as you've been saying, there it is, the 'fuzziness of the language') (http://www.ibtimes.com/irans-foreign-minister-denies-missiles-violate-un-resolution-says-they-are-self-2336539)

The US will push for Security Council action in the face of a sure Russian veto.  This means the US is not deeply committed to Security Council action.  There may yet be US sanctions, but not until after the Security Council dance is well and truly ended. Since the US is clearly in no hurry, this could be a while.
The U.S. congress may twist arms to impose new sanctions, but the current President will not sign the legislation unless something catastrophic happens and he is left with no choice.
Adjusting up a bit based on recent provocative actions by Iran. Still a low-prob event due to the desire of most parties for recent deals to be perceived as successful.
U.S. sanctions ruled out by Russia.

Iran has just gone out of sanctions and is still in need of cash enhanced by oil trade and contracts performance until then,  leaving them with little interest in pulling back from steps made towards international integration.  Plus,  the fact that civil society showed ever more eagerness to support reformists demonstrated recently both at the General Assembly and the  Assembly of Experts, means that openness has been gaining momentum.

Comments:
No love lost between Obama and Netanyahu, but this is an election year; GOP and Clinton will use this as a yelling point. RU and PRC as permanent members of the UNSC will most likely block any UN action. If EU, led by FR, imposes sanctions for continued tests, USA may be pressured into following. 
Adjusting up.

While Congress has been calling for new sanctions based on the recent ballistic missile tests, Obama and Kerry have expended too much political capital to not try and make the nuclear deal work. Also, there will be some significant chunks of time where congress will not be in session that will reduce the likelihood of passing a bill on this issue (i.e. summer recess). While the state department has indicated it is exploring unilateral action, Obama nor Kerry have indicated a desire to impose new sanctions by executive order.
Popular opinion in Iran is moving towards reform but not aggressively that it could cause political unrest. President Obama is politically motivated to make the nuclear deal work.

US has scheduled a UN Security Council meetin on Monday.  Security Council Resolution 2231 reportedly intended to prevent Iran from launching nuclear capable missiles.  While not a violation of the nuclear agreement, it may lead to new sanctions. -- NYTimes 3/12 a6

Got a little carried away yesterday with my jump up to 100.

Members of the U.S. Congress are pushing for new sanctions in response to Iran’s recent ballistic missile tests. Iran denies that the tests violated its international nuclear agreement or U.N. resolutions. Yesterday, a U.N. spokesperson said Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon is urging Iran to show restraint and stop its missile testing, saying, “In the current political atmosphere in the Middle East region, and so soon after the positive news of the lifting of sanctions against Iran, the secretary-general calls on the government of the Islamic Republic of Iran to act with moderation, caution and the good sense not to increase tensions through any hasty actions.”
http://foreignpolicy.com/2016/03/11/u-s-to-consider-new-sanctions-after-iranian-missile-tests/
* * *

After the last set of missile tests and took about 3 months for new sanctions be imposed. By that measure, new sanctions could be in place by October. However, it seems unlikely that Congress would take such a big step before the election.

I am raising my estimate from 10 to 22 due to two factors: 1. Iran's recent testing of ballistic missiles. Second, Hillary Clinton is calling for sanctions for these tests. http://www.reuters.com/article/us-iran-missiles-idUSKCN0WB0I9

Dateline 3-9-16 Iran carried out a series of ballistic missile tests from underground silos on Tuesday in exercises dubbed "The Power of Velayat," as the U.S. promised diplomatic retaliation. Iran claims the missiles in Tuesday's exercise have ranges of up to 2,000 kilometers, which if true would put Israel within striking distance. U.S. diplomats say they're cooking up an "appropriate response" to the tests. And FPâ€™s John Hudson reports that some members of Congress are pushing for more sanctions, and more action by Washington. The missile exercises don't violate the recently-signed Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action nuclear agreement with Iran, but the U.S. says they do violate preexisting United Nations Security Council resolutions prohibiting ballistic missile tests. Situation Report: Foreign Policy [fp@foreignpolicy.com]

Iran Test-Fires 2 More Ballistic Missiles Despite Threat Of New Sanctions From US.  Iran test fired two new ballistic missiles early today despite threats of new sanctions from the US just the day before when, according to Reuters, it claimed to have "test-fired several missiles from underground silos" that hit a target 434 miles away. The missiles tested today were fired from the northern part of the country, hitting a location in the south as far as 870 miles. Sounds like Iran is on a roll.

This doesn't sound like a nation that is becoming more moderate. OK, the U.N. isn't enthusiastic about protecting Israel. But I expect the Security Council members would not like for Iran to make good on these threats. Israel has nuclear weapons and the means to deliver them and the fallout -- literally -- would affect a good part of the planet.

"As the cases described above demonstrate, Iran has relied on illicit procurement networks in strategic diversion points, such as Turkey, to advance its nuclear and missile programs.  Even with the nuclear agreement in place, Iran may continue to procure missile and arms related items illicitly because it does not accept an ongoing U.N. ban on such trade.  Therefore countries should exercise extra vigilance in exporting such items to known transshipment hubs, like Turkey.  If these countries served as a hub for illicit trade in the past – when stringent international sanctions were in place – there is every chance that their role will expand in the future, as trade flows to Iran increase. "

My 9% chance of yes really means "no."  I expect Iran will continue to make it difficult to verify what their nuclear intentions.  Since they need money, and since our President has "worked" this deal, my forecast is that the status quo will continue and Iran will try to stockpile as much money for oil as they can while economic sanctions are lifted.  Once their true intentions are again realized by the West, Iran knows that it is only time before economic sanctions are once again imposed against them.  There goal is to become a nuclear power and they will say and do whatever it takes to get them to that goal.

Iran has currently several reasons that support avoiding further sanctions, including:
- Getting the benefits from the nuclear deal including: ability to sell oil, unfreezing of foreign assets and access to foreign financial markets
- Being consistent with the last elections which confirmed the electorate preference for the reformists
- Adherence so far with the requirements of the nuclear deal
The current agreement is relatively new and the world will wait to see how the agreement is holding before making new moves.

This is election year and as much as current administration doesn't want to impose sanctions, for purely ideological reasons, not doing so hurts Democrat's chances of maintaining WH. Sanctions against Iran have twofold effect: 1) removing Iranian oil from market helps stabilize price and the economy (make WS/BB happy) and 2) sends message to electorate that the current and subsequent Democrat WH is tough on terror and serious about US' standing on the global stage.

The Iran deal will remain in sharp focus is US political circles heading into the US presidential elections. While the US and Iran's administrations will do everything in their power to support the deal, parliaments of both countries are strongly opposed to the deal and have high vested interests to thwart it. It is important to note that new sanctions imposed by the US or the UN do not necessarily nullify the nuclear deal. This was evident in the Jan 2016 sanctions that took effect even as Iran released some high-profile prisoners. Based primarily on either country's parliament wanting to show its government down, I think it is likely that the US or the UN impose additional sanctions against Iran before the first anniversary of the deal.

From a US domestic perspective, Obama and his administration have staked a lot on the Iran deal. Approving additional sanctions will be seen as implicitly conceding that the Iran deal was no good. The new missiles do increase the chance of it happening, but it may take a change of administration to change things. As it is, I also think it unlikely that the UN will approve sanctions if the US does not agree.

per the lads (@scholarandcat, @clinton, @einsteinjs), Iran shows no signs of backing off from its ballistic missile testing program, and further tests (very likely to occur) are also likely to incur further sanctions. The people in control of the missile testing program are not necessarily the same as those in control of JCPOA implementation, and anyway Rouhani seems to be on board with their agenda wrt missile testing (in public at least). I think the consensus on this one is way out and would like to see a detailed explanation from someone on the other side as to why it isn't.

If Iran follows the agreement and according to the IAEA (https://www.iaea.org/newscenter/focus/Iran) they have, it seems unlikely that there will be need for additional sanctions. I have not heard new sanctions on Iran coming from the Republican Presidential candidates so it seems to be out of the conservative cross hairs for the moment in the US. Should Iran be seen as uncooperative against IS will need to push this up. With the US presidential elections underway, small stories can get blown out of proportion by candidates and the media. So there's always that possibility: Iran detaining US journalists, "discovery" of a economic or military deals with North Korea, etc. it's the Rumsfeld unknown unknowns that are likely to take us by surprise. Having said all that, Rouhnai's recent visits to European capitals seems to be quickly thawing relations.

Why ruin a perfectly agreeable and possibly congenial anniversary date when you can just target "individuals and entities" per @Moomtastic
Better question would be how many G20 heads of state will be there on such auspicious date.

It's important to note that the new sanctions are being levied against "individuals and entities" associated with Iran, but not on the country itself. As it stands, there aren't a lot more sanctions the US can impose on Iran, unilatterally, and the UN hasn't added any sanctions to Iran since 2010. The most devastating sanctions in recent history were the 2012 EU sanctions against Iranian petro-chemicals. (http://www.cfr.org/iran/international-sanctions-iran/p20258). If the US really were upset over Iranian cheating, they'd likely go to Brussels (and also avoid a Russian or Chinese veto in the UN).
There is a very strong desire within the US administration to be seen playing nicely with Iran, with any disputes carefully choreographed on both sides.  Needs watching, though.

Iran is going through many changes at the moment, with the old guard hanging onto past policies, and the new guard attempting to influence and shift policy. Recently some Iranians who were barred from political office had their status changed to allow political campaigning, though it remains to be seen who may emerge from this action. Iran likely does not fully trust some recent actions and agreements, and wiser individuals often hedge their bets. The bigger change evolving is the positive impact to the Iranian economy, and this may lessen the possibility of "inappropriate" actions in 2016. The more economically engaged that Iran becomes, the less the risk, or need for new sanctions. The wild card in this is actions in Syria, which may result in contentious activity.

To me, the missile issue was the only area of overt contention, and sanctions were passed already.  My opinion is that the Obama administration does not want to make any waves in its last year in office, with respect to Iran in particular.  Sanctions in the UN would be a tough sell with Russia.  I am still leaving a little room here, just in case Iran does something particularly outrageous.

No. The U.S. (by which I mean Obama, taking some quiet hints from HRC) has what they want out of the Iran deal and from now until the election they will do everything they can to try to keep things in "cruise control" mode where stuff happens administratively and with little to no political debate. From the Iranian perspective, I think even the hardliners are enjoying reading about how well Iran's economy is doing compared to S.A. Everybody is just going to keep a lid on whatever comes up for a while.
Not unless Iran cheats on the nuclear deal and I believe they really want to "join the world."

The US and EU sanctions were just lifted in January. So, really the question is "will Iran do anything to warrant sanctions." Russian companies are trying to get into Iran already, and there has to be an economic rebound that will at least keep the ball moving in the right direction. Will Israel do something to provoke them? That is a legit question, but given pro-democratic movements i think the odds are low.

Yes, new sanctions will most likely be applied because Iran's hardliners from the Revolutionary Guard are going to beat the drum of aggression and do something aggressive that will require additional sanctions.  It might be rocket launches, lack of inspection transparency, or even an attack on a US Naval ship.
Unlikely to be related to the nuclear deal, but the US would impose new sanctions if Iran tests another missile.
Internal political pressure will drive Iran to continue ballistic missile tests
At the present time Iran is doing everything necessary to get back to normal international relations.  If additional sanctions occur all bets would be off on the nuclear deal.

I can't see this happening. For Obama and Kerry, it would be a huge admission of defeat. In addition, they would know that the rest of the world won't play along, so it would not be effective anyway. And, the Iranians would not want to push it to a point where even Kerry feels he must sanction them. I'm going to start this at 0%, and will raise it only if some tension develops.
Maybe. If Iran does something that the Republican candidate can point to that makes the democrats look soft, some kind of meaningless sanctions might be slapped on to make the whole thing go away.

Not until 
1. Republicans are in office
2. The fight against ISIS winds down

I don't think the UN will, since it would need the support of Russia and China to do so. The US Congress might, and in certain circumstances Obama may not use his veto. The section of Iran's government that is responsible for developing missiles and supporting regimes in Iraq and Syria could do something that provokes a new round of sanctions, but the chances appear to be low at this time.

Check out the Vice video series on Iran, or just random Tehran videos. These sanctions lack consequences on both sides of the barricades. I am not surprised that US gov imposes them, and I expect more tantrums.

I see this IFP as very similar to one of the other IFPs that was just published about removing Iran from the state sponsors of terrorism list (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/129699), so I'll include a passage of my reasoning from there:

The revolutionary guard in Iran runs many lucrative businesses , dominates power, media, industries , smuggling / trade from A-Z, but 
 missile defense as its called  is their  baby  .
parallel to nuclear advances Iran  has invested significantly in missiles (rockets) tecnology .
They have tested missiles and they will do again  in special days as they see fit.  
So I guess US  sanctions are a possibility , but I donot see UN sanctions .
as some one said before me, the idea of the negotiations were  to open the door to direct contacts to avoid inconveniences .

Right now this seems improbable, given everyone's grim determination to play nicely with the other children. However, whenever playing children are involved, things can turn ugly pretty fast.  So far, so good...
They still have Hezbollah under sanctions will likely stay targeted on specific covert organizations.

This is unlikely. The nuclear deal wasn't just about uranium and centrifuges, it was a first step toward welcoming Iran back into the good graces of the global community. The fight against ISIS has changed the equation in the middle east, and the West has no choice to but to grudgingly accept Iran as an ally against a common enemy. As other official sanctions are lifted, countries will have more economic tools to put pressure on Iran and the UN won't be as necessary. Iran is happily counting money and they no longer need to do things like missile tests to get international attention. I don't think they want to risk any of the gains they've made recently.

The US Congress has lots of ideas on this that aren't likely to make it to an Obama signing. The Executive could impose his own, as he did recently for the missile test. Iran could test another missile.
Would go lower (don't expect reasonable things to pass the US Congress and be signed by President Obama) but there is a possibility that something narrow (cyber-related) might be imposed.
Sanctions targeted against individuals for reasons other than a breach of the nuclear deal are possible.
no, unless Iran does something bat$#@( crazy.   as imposing sanctions would make Obama admin. look like fools for their initial deal.
No new sanctions just yet, UN will wait it out.
I firmly feel that Iran will fail to comply with the requirments of the "Iran Nuclear Agreement" particularly the UN inspection of Iran Nuclear Facilities.
The nuclear deal makes this unlikely to me.
